Loose stools, failure to thrive, anemia, bloating, irregular bowel habits, migraine, ataxia

Diarrhea, weight loss, persistent villous atrophy

Response to gluten

Histopathological Finding

Crypt hyperplasia, lactase deficiency, steatorrhea

Normal intraepithelial lymphocyte population, clonal expansion of CD3+ lymphocytes (Type 2)

Negative biopsy and serology

Complications

Refractory celiac sprue, enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, intestinal cancer, hyposplenism, small bowel adenocarcinoma

Same complications as celiac sprue

None reported

Treatment

Strict dietary elimination (Gluten-Free Diet) + Iron Supplementation

Strict gluten-free diet, serological follow-up, biopsy if needed

Avoidance of gluten-containing foods

Diagnosis

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody (IgA levels), anti-endomysial antibody, anti-deamidated antigliadin antibody, small intestinal mucosal biopsy

Based on clinical response, repeated biopsy if necessary

Clinical response to gluten challenge

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of a malodorous vaginal discharge and mild irritation. On examination, the following picture is observed. Microscopic examination of a wet mount reveals the presence of clue cells. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Bacterial vag

Aspect

Description

Definition

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common vaginal infection characterized by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora, with a shift from lactobacilli to anaerobic bacteria.

Clinical Features

Vaginal Discharge: Thin, grayish-white, and adherent to the vaginal walls.

 

Odor: Characteristically has a "fishy" odor, especially after sexual intercourse.

 

Irritation: Mild irritation may be present, but significant inflammation or erythema is usually absent.

Microscopic Findings

Clue Cells: Vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, seen on wet mount microscopy. Clue cells more than or equal to 20% of epithelial cells is diagnostic

Diagnostic Criteria

Presence of three out of four Amsel criteria: thin, homogenous discharge, positive whiff test, pH greater than 4.5, and the presence of clue cells on microscopy.

Causative Factors

Disruption of the normal balance of vaginal flora, often associated with sexual activity, douching, or antibiotic use.

Association with Sexual Activity

BV is more common in sexually active women, but it can also occur in those who are not sexually active.

Complications

Increased risk of preterm birth and other gynecological infections.

Treatment

Antibiotics, typically metronidazole or clindamycin, are used to treat BV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. On hormonal evaluation, the patient is found to have an increased luteinizing hormone (LH): follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this hormonal profile?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Aspect

Description

Definition

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine disorder characterized by hormonal imbalance, ovarian dysfunction, and the presence of polycystic ovaries.

Clinical Features

Menstrual Irregularities: Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or irregular menstrual cycles.

 

Hyperandrogenism: Clinical signs such as hirsutism, acne, and male-pattern hair loss.

 

Polycystic Ovaries: Enlarged ovaries with multiple small follicles on ultrasound examination.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. Her medical history reveals early initiation of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, and a history of smoking. She has not received the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine. What is the most significant predisposing factor for cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Lack of HPV v

Predisposing Factor

Description

Human Papillomavirus (HPV)

High-Risk Types: Infection with high-risk HPV types, particularly HPV 16 and 18, is the primary cause of cervical cancer.

Early Initiation of Sexual Activity

Initiation of sexual activity at a young age increases the risk of HPV exposure and infection.

Multiple Sexual Partners

Having multiple sexual partners increases the likelihood of exposure to high-risk HPV strains.

History of Smoking

Smoking is considered a cofactor that may enhance the carcinogenic effects of HPV, increasing cervical cancer risk.

Immunosuppression

Weakened immune system due to conditions such as HIV/AIDS or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility to HPV infection.

Lack of HPV Vaccination

Failure to receive the HPV vaccine increases the risk of infection with high-risk HPV types.

Long-Term Use of Oral Contraceptives

Prolonged use of oral contraceptives has been associated with a slightly increased risk of cervical cancer.

High Parity

Multiple pregnancies, especially those resulting in many full-term births, may be associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

Family History of Cervical Cancer

A family history of cervical cancer may indicate a genetic predisposition or shared environmental factors.

Socioeconomic Factors

Low socioeconomic status and limited access to healthcare may contribute to delayed screening and treatment, increasing the risk of cervical cancer.

Chlamydia Infection

Some studies suggest an association between chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection and an increased risk of cervical cancer.

Dietary Factors

Diets low in fruits and vegetables and high in red meat may be associated with a higher risk of cervical cancer.

Environmental Exposures

Exposure to certain environmental factors, such as exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero, may increase the risk of cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports a positive home pregnancy test and a history of irregular menstrual cycles. On examination, she appears distressed, and pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an adnexal mass with no intrauterine gestational sac. The patient's vital signs are stable. What is the most likely site of ectopic pregnancy in this case?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Fallopian tu

Site of Ectopic Pregnancy

Description

Fallopian Tube (Most Common)

Approximately 95% of all ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube. The ampulla is the most common site.

Ovary

Ectopic pregnancies in the ovary are rare.

Interstitial or Cornual (within the uterine wall)

Implantation within the interstitial or cornual part of the fallopian tube, close to the uterine cavity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea for several years. She describes the pain as deep, aching, and often worsening during menstruation. She also reports pain during sexual intercourse. The patient has a regular menstrual cycle and no significant gynecological history. On pelvic examination, there is tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix, and a fixed retroverted uterus is noted. Transvaginal ultrasound is given. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of new-onset high blood pressure. She denies any history of hypertension or renal disease. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. There is no proteinuria on dipstick testing. Fetal monitoring reveals no signs of distress. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a 24-hour urine collection for protein estimation

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate hospitalization for induction of labor

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours

questions.correct_answer: D. Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hou

Definition

Elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg) that develops after 20 weeks of gestation.

Proteinuria

Absence of significant proteinuria (important to differentiate from preeclampsia).

Risk Factors

Primigravidae, multiple gestation, maternal age <20 or >35, obesity, chronic kidney disease, and diabetes.

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic; may have mild symptoms like headache or visual changes in pre eclampsia.

Complications

Can progress to preeclampsia, especially if associated with proteinuria or other signs of end-organ dysfunction.

Fetal Monitoring

Fetal well-being should be assessed through regular antenatal monitoring (kick counts, non-stress tests, etc.).

questions.text: A 32-year-old couple presents to the fertility clinic with a history of infertility for the past 18 months. The husband reports a normal sexual history with no known medical conditions. The wife's menstrual cycles are regular, and her hormone levels are within normal limits. As part of the initial infertility workup, a semen analysis is ordered for the husband. The results reveal a low sperm count (oligospermia), decreased sperm motility, and a high percentage of morphologically abnormal sperm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome)

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure lasts for approximately 3 minutes. On regaining consciousness, the patient is noted to have elevated blood pressure (170/110 mmHg) and mild epigastric pain. Initial investigations reveal proteinuria on urine dipstick. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Administer magnesium su

Diagnosis

Eclampsia is diagnosed in the presence of seizures in a woman with preeclampsia, characterized by hypertension and proteinuria, or in the absence of these features.

Initial Stabilization

Ensure patient safety during the seizure episode, protecting airway and preventing injury.

Immediate Seizure Control

Magnesium sulfate: First-line agent for seizure control. Administered intravenously.

 

Alternative: Diazepam or lorazepam may be used if magnesium sulfate is not available.

Blood Pressure Control

Antihypertensive therapy: Initiate if severe hypertension persists after seizure control. Options include labetalol, hydralazine, or nifedipine. Avoid rapid blood pressure reduction.

Maternal and Fetal Monitoring

Continuous monitoring of vital signs, neurological status, urine output, and fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the postpartum unit after a vaginal delivery. Her pregnancy and labor were uneventful. The delivery was completed without complications, and the placenta was delivered intact. Approximately 30 minutes after delivery, the patient complains of increased vaginal bleeding. On examination, the fundus is firm, but the bleeding persists. Initial attempts to control bleeding with uterine massage and administration of oxytocin have been ineffective. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Perform a bimanual uterine examination
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Perform a bimanual uterine Management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) Definition Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as blood loss exceeding 500 ml after a vaginal delivery or 1,000 ml after a cesarean section. Primary Causes

  • Uterine atony: Failure of the uterus to contract adequately after delivery.
  • Retained placental tissue: Incomplete expulsion of the placenta.
  • Genital tract lacerations: Tears in the birth canal, including the cervix and vagina.
  • Uterine inversion or rupture: Rare but serious complications.
Initial Management
  • Identify Cause of bleeding.
  • Uterine massage: Stimulate uterine contractions.
  • Administer oxytocin: A uterotonic medication to enhance uterine contractions.
  • Empty the bladder: A full bladder can impede uterine contraction.
First-Line Medications
  • Oxytocin: Stimulates uterine contractions.
  • Methylergonovine or carboprost: Additional uterotonic agents.
Surgical Interventions
  • Bimanual uterine examination: Identify and remove retained placental tissue.
  • Genital tract repair: Suturing lacerations.
  • Uterine artery embolization: Interventional radiology procedure to control bleeding.
  • Surgical exploration: In cases of uterine rupture or inversion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G3P2, at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports no antenatal complications until now. On examination, the uterus is tense, and there is tenderness on palpation. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the immediate management for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine atony; uterine massage and oxytocin

questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Abruptio placenta; immediate deliv

 

Abruptio placenta

Definition

Abruptio placenta is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery.

Incidence

Approximately 1% of pregnancies.

Risk Factors

Maternal hypertension (especially preeclampsia).

 

Hypertension, Pre eclamptic toxemia

 

Previous abruption

 

Multiparity and elderly gravida

Clinical Presentation

Sudden-onset abdominal pain: Often severe and continuous.

 

Vaginal bleeding: May be concealed (hidden behind the placenta) or apparent, depending on the degree of separation.

 

Uterine tenderness: Palpable abdominal tenderness due to uterine contractions.

 

Fetal distress: Signs of fetal compromise, including non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound may reveal retroplacental clot or hematoma, but diagnosis is often clinical.

Management

Immediate delivery: Delivery is the definitive treatment to minimize maternal and fetal risks.

 

Cesarean section: Often required, especially if there is significant maternal or fetal compromise.

 

Blood transfusion: If significant blood loss has occurred.

 

Maternal monitoring: Assess vital signs, coagulation profile, and response to interventions.

 

Fetal monitoring: Continuous monitoring to assess fetal well-being.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and discomfort during intercourse. On pelvic examination, the physician notes tenderness in the rectouterine pouch and suspects the presence of a pelvic pathology. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - E

Location

Situated in the pelvic cavity.

Alternative Names

Douglas pouch or cul-de-sac.

Anatomy

Space between the posterior wall of the uterus and the anterior surface of the rectum.

Communication

Communicates with the peritoneal cavity, allowing fluid or blood to collect in the pouch.

Clinical Significance

Pelvic Examinations: Tenderness in the rectouterine pouch may be noted during pelvic examinations.

 

Pathological Conditions: Various pelvic pathologies may involve or affect the rectouterine pouch.

Common Pathologies

Endometriosis: Ectopic endometrial tissue may cause inflammation and tenderness in the pouch.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): Infection and inflammation of the female reproductive organs.

 

Ovarian Cysts: Large ovarian cysts may cause distension and discomfort in the pouch.

Imaging and Evaluation

Transvaginal Ultrasound: Useful for visualizing the pouch and assessing pelvic pathology.

 

Pelvic MRI: Provides detailed imaging for further evaluation of pelvic structures and abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of abnormal vaginal bleeding between menstrual cycles. She reports occasional pelvic discomfort but denies any pain during intercourse. On pelvic examination, a soft, less than 1 cm, reddish-purple, finger-like projection is noted on the cervix. The patient has no significant medical history, and Pap smear results from the previous year were normal. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - S

Management of Cervical Polyp

Diagnosis

  • Clinical evaluation during pelvic examination.

  • Visualization of a soft, reddish or purple, finger-like projection on the cervix.

  • May be associated with abnormal vaginal bleeding or pelvic discomfort.

Confirmation

  • Histological examination of the excised polyp after simple polypectomy.

Indications for Management

  • Presence of symptoms such as abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic discomfort, or other related concerns.

First-Line Treatment

  • Simple Polypectomy: Surgical removal of the cervical polyp, often performed in the office setting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of upper abdominal pain, headache, and visual disturbances. She reports nausea and malaise over the past 24 hours. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg), and she has epigastric tenderness. Laboratory tests are given. What is the appropriate management in this case? Mean laboratory findings in the HELLP syndrome Hb% 8.752 gm% Reticulocyte count (%) 2.163 Platelet count (cmm) 94375 LDH (u/l) 1065.73 Total bilirubin (mg/dl) 3.17 AST (u/l) 146.34 ALT (u/l) 139.74 Haemolysis in peripheral blood smear (n) 38
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Prompt deliv

Definition

  • A severe variant of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis (H), Elevated Liver enzymes (EL), and a Low Platelet count (LP).

Clinical Presentation

  • Upper abdominal pain (epigastric pain).

  • Headache and visual disturbances.

  • Nausea, malaise, and vomiting.

  • Elevated blood pressure.

Laboratory Findings

  • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count <100,000/mm³).

  • Elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT).

  • Hemolysis (evidenced by elevated lactate dehydrogenase and bilirubin levels, and low haptoglobin).

Diagnosis

  • Based on clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

  • May be associated with preeclampsia.

Management

  • Prompt Delivery: The mainstay of management to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

  • Delivery is often recommended, even if the fetus is premature.

  • Decision for delivery based on the severity of the syndrome, gestational age, and maternal and fetal conditions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the obstetric clinic with concerns about a possible pregnancy. She reports missing her last menstrual period, experiencing breast tenderness, and feeling nauseous in the mornings. She also mentions increased frequency of urination. On examination, her breasts are mildly enlarged, and the areolas appear darker than usual. She denies any recent illness or changes in medication. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the most likely signs observed in this patient that support the diagnosis of pregnancy?

options.label: B
options.text: Breast tenderness and darkening of areolas

questions.correct_answer: B. Breast tenderness and darkening of areolas
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Breast tenderness and darkening

Physiological System

Changes During Pregnancy

Cardiovascular System

  • Increased blood volume and cardiac output

  • Decreased systemic vascular resistance

  • Physiological anemia due to increased plasma volume

  • Enlargement of the heart and displacement of the diaphragm

Respiratory System

  • Increased tidal volume and minute ventilation

  • Elevated diaphragm and increased oxygen consumption

  • Potential respiratory alkalosis due to enhanced ventilation

Renal System

  • Increased renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate

  • Mild dilation of the renal pelvis and ureters

  • Physiological hydronephrosis (due to hormonal effects)

Gastrointestinal System

  • Delayed gastric emptying and increased gastric acid secretion

  • Relaxation of smooth muscle leading to slowed intestinal transit

  • Increased risk of constipation and hemorrhoids

Endocrine System

  • Elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

  • Increased production of estrogen and progesterone

  • Insulin resistance and potential gestational diabetes

Musculoskeletal System

  • Softening of ligaments due to hormonal changes

  • Shift in the center of gravity and changes in posture

  • Increased risk of musculoskeletal discomfort and back pain

Hematological System

  • Physiological hypercoagulability

  • Increased clotting factors and decreased fibrinolysis

  • Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

Immunological System

  • Modulation of the immune response to tolerate the fetus

  • Increased susceptibility to certain infections

  • Altered response to allergies and autoimmune conditions

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a noticeable bulge in the vaginal area, along with difficulty with urination and incomplete emptying of the bladder. She has a history of multiple vaginal deliveries and reports that the symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past year. On examination, a visible bulge in the anterior vaginal wall is noted during a Valsalva maneuver. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Pelvic floor exercises (Kegel exercises)

Management of Genital Prolapse

 

Pelvic Floor Exercises (Kegel Exercises)

  • Strengthening exercises for pelvic floor muscles.

  • Aim to improve pelvic organ support and alleviate symptoms.

Pessary Placement

  • Device inserted into the vagina to provide pelvic organ support.

  • Non-surgical option that helps alleviate symptoms.

Surgical Repair

  • Reserved for cases where conservative measures are ineffective.

  • Different surgical approaches based on the type and severity of prolapse.

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)

  • Not a primary treatment for genital prolapse.

  • May be considered for menopausal symptoms but does not address pelvic floor weakness.

Patient Education and Lifestyle Modifications

  • Educate patients on pelvic floor health and prolapse prevention.

  • Lifestyle modifications may include weight management and avoiding heavy lifting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine examination. As part of the assessment, the healthcare provider evaluates the pelvic dimensions to determine the suitability for a vaginal delivery. On examination, the pelvis is noted to have a round inlet, a generous subpubic arch, and a wide sciatic notch. What type of pelvic shape is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Pelvis

Inlet Shape

Outlet Shape

Pubic Arch

Sciatic Notch

Clinical Significance

Gynecoid Pelvis
  • Round
  • Round
  • Wide (> 90 degrees)
  • Wide
  • Most favorable for vaginal delivery.

Android Pelvis
  • Heart-shaped
  • Narrow
  • Narrow
  • Narrow
  • May pose challenges during childbirth.

Anthropoid Pelvis
  • Oval
  • Variable
  • Variable
  • Variable
  • Generally suitable for vaginal delivery, but shape influences the birthing process.

Platypelloid Pelvis
  • Transversely widened
  • Flat
  • Variable
  • Variable
  • Associated with challenges during labor, may require careful management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with progressing labor. During the second stage of labor, the obstetrician decides to use the following instrument to assist with the delivery. What is the primary indication for using this instrument in this scenario?
questions.correct_answer: D. Prolonged second stage of labor
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Prolonged second stag

Type of Forceps

  • Obstetrical forceps designed for use during the second stage of labor.

Blade Configuration

  • Double curved blades with a transverse application to the fetal head.

Primary Indication

  • Prolonged second stage of labor, specifically when there is delayed descent of the fetal head.

Application Technique

  • Applied transversely to the fetal head to facilitate traction and rotation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage III ovarian carcinoma following surgical exploration. The tumor is cytoreduced to minimal residual disease. The histopathology report indicates high-grade serous carcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel

options.label: B
options.text: Radiation therapy to the pelvic area

questions.correct_answer: A. Adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin

Surgery

  • Primary treatment involves surgical exploration, debulking, and staging. Cytoreduction aims to achieve minimal residual disease. Surgical options include hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and omentectomy.

Adjuvant Chemotherapy

  • Following surgery, adjuvant chemotherapy is typically administered. The standard regimen includes a combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel.

Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy

  • In some cases, especially when cytoreduction is challenging, neoadjuvant chemotherapy may be administered before surgery to shrink the tumor.

Targeted Therapies

  • Bevacizumab, a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor, may be used in combination with chemotherapy for advanced-stage ovarian carcinoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with a history of short stature, delayed puberty, and amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, low-set ears, and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. A karyotype analysis is ordered to confirm the diagnosis. What chromosomal abnormality is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Genetics

  • Monosomy X (45,X) is the most common chromosomal abnormality, where one X chromosome is completely missing. Other karyotypes, such as mosaic patterns, may also occur.

Clinical Features

  • Short stature, delayed puberty, webbed neck, low-set ears, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, infertility, cardiovascular abnormalities, and renal anomalies.

Cardiovascular Monitoring

  • Regular monitoring for cardiovascular anomalies, particularly aortic coarctation, is essential for early detection and intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a gynecology clinic in India requesting a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) at 8 weeks gestation. She has been on Combined oral contraceptive pills for 2 years with perfect adherence and no side effects. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India, what is the maximum gestational age limit within which a medical termination of pregnancy can be legally performed?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 24 week

Objective

  • Regulates the conditions under which medical termination of pregnancy (abortion) may be performed in India.

Legal Gestational Limit

  • Termination is legally permitted up to 20 weeks of gestation. Beyond 20 weeks, termination is allowed only under exceptional circumstances and with the approval of a medical board.

Who Can Perform Abortions

  • Registered medical practitioners (RMPs) with recognized qualifications are authorized to perform abortions. Qualified nurses and auxiliary nurse-midwives can also provide early-stage abortions.

Conditions for Termination

  • Risk to the life of the pregnant woman or grave injury to her physical or mental health. 

  • Risk of substantial fetal abnormalities.

  • Contraceptive failure in the case of a married woman.

Approval for Termination Beyond 20 Weeks

  • Termination beyond 20 weeks requires the opinion of two registered medical practitioners and approval from a medical board.

Informed Consent

  • The woman's consent is required for termination. In the case of minors, the consent of a guardian is necessary.

Government Approved Centers

  • Termination can only be performed in government-approved facilities or centers.

Record Keeping

  • Detailed records of each termination, including the reason for the termination, must be maintained by the medical practitioner.

Rahul tells the doctor that his weight is 65kg, is an IT professional and has a sedentary lifestyle. According to the latest NIN RDA guidelines, how many calories should Rahul take?

Type 1 error

Type 2 error

  • b error

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has recently been diagnosed with HCC. He was a worker in a groundnut oil factory for the past 25 years. He used to eat stale groundnuts that were rejected by the factory managers. Contamination of groundnuts with which of the following would have caused this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Aspergillus parasiticu

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing in the garden when he was scratched by a street dog. The boy is rushed to the hospital immediately. On examination, There was a minor abrasion only without bleeding. What is the best management for this boy?

options.label: C
options.text: Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins

questions.correct_answer: C. Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Local wound cleaning and rabies v

Categories of contact with suspect rabid animal

Post-exposure Prophylaxis

Category-1: Licks or touch on intact skin.

  • The integrity of the skin is not broken.
  • It has not broken, or exposed
  • Local wound management

Category-2: Minor scratches or Abrasions without bleeding.

  • If bleeding occurs even a single drop, then it comes under Category 3.
  • Integrity of the skin is broken.
  • Local wound management
  • Immediate Rabies vaccination

Category-3:

  • It can be a single bite or multiple transdermal bites.
  • Bleeding occurs.
  • Licks are not on intact skin but on broken skin.
  • Contamination of mucus membrane from the saliva through licks.
  • Contact with bats
  • Wild animal bite.
  • Wound management
  • Rabies vaccination
  • Rabies immunoglobulin administration

questions.text: In a prospective study comprising 10000 subjects, 6000 subjects were put on beta carotene and 4000 were not. 3 out of the ﬁrst 6000 developed lung cancer and 2 out of the second 4000 developed lung cancer. What is the interpretation of the above?

options.label: C
options.text: The study design is not sufficient to draw any meaningful conclusions

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the dosage of iron and folic acid tablets given under the anemia mukt bharat scheme to pregnant females?

options.label: A
options.text: 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic 5 days per week

options.label: B
options.text: 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily

options.label: C
options.text: 50 mg Fe & 400 mcg folic acid daily

questions.correct_answer: B. 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid

Prophylactic Dose and Regime for Iron Folic Acid Supplementation

 

Age group

Dose and Regime

Children 6-59 months of age

Bi-weekly 1ml Iron and Folic Acid syrup. Each ml Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of Folic Acid. Bottle (50ml) to have an ‘auto-dispenser’ and information leaflet as per MoHFW guidelines in the mono-carton.

Children 5-9 years of age

Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet. Each tablet containing 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg folic Acid, sugar-coated, pink-colour.

School-going Adolescent Girls and Boys, 10-19 years of age Out-of-school Adolescent Girls, 10-19 years of age

Women of Reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating) 20-49 years (Under Mission Parivar Vikas)

Women of Reproductive Age (non-pregnant, non-lactating) 20-49 years

Weekly, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet, Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic Acid, sugar-coated and red-colour.

Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers (of 0-6 months child)

Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (that is from the second trimester), continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy) and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum Each tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid, sugar-coated and red-colour.
